channel.title: Determining the operating system of a connected socket

item.title: Determining the operating system of a connected socket
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I thought this was going to be an interesting discussion on how to do this as well, an open source tool that does this is ‘nmap’, you could have a look at that. But this code would almost certainly need to be in a native language, Java doesn’t let you go that deep.

But, as other people said, for what you want to do you should just have the client request the type of binaries that it wants.

Read full topic
item.source: Determining the operating system of a connected socket

item.title: Determining the operating system of a connected socket
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

TCP/IP Fingerprint Specifics

Certain parameters within the TCP protocol definition are left up to the implementation. Different operating systems, and different versions of the same operating system, set different defaults for these values. By collecting and examining these values, one may differentiate among various operating systems, and implementations of TCP/IP.[1] The TCP/IP fields that may vary include the following:

Initial packet size (16 bits)
Initial TTL (8 bits)
Window size (16 bits)
Max segment size (16 bits)
Window scaling value (8 bits)
"don't fragment" flag (1 bit)
"sackOK" flag (1 bit)
"nop" flag (1 bit)

These values may be combined to form a 67-bit signature, or fingerprint, for the target machine.[2] Just inspecting the Initial TTL and window size fields is often enough in order to successfully identify an operating system, which eases the task of performing manual OS fingerprinting.[3]

From wikipedia.

Read full topic

item.title: Determining the operating system of a connected socket
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Mopman:

Didn’t see the original question, but just going off the title I dunno why you got such a weird reaction - fingerprinting various parameters of TCP stuff is often a perfectly viable way of determining the OS of the machine you’re connected to.

I didn’t think it was possible but I’ll check into this. It was a truthful question but of course I knew there would be some insulting involved.

t4:

the moment you learn that someone of equal or lesser capabilities than yourself gets awarded for their knowledge/achievements and you do not!

Ah yes. You and so many other deserving people.

item.title: Determining the operating system of a connected socket
item.dc:creator: @Phillipe Phillipé
item.description:
@Phillipe wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:3, topic:432720”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=535430.msg3914505#msg3914505 date=1329040382]
Did you receive the javaguru badge for being an idiot?
[/quote]

The nature of the question was more or less directed towards some client hacking work I am doing where Jagex automatically expects their ondemand server to know what native libraries are required for the client so I think the question is within reason. Piss off.

Edit: Going to assume that there are some other workings with the web server/local application because the question has an obvious answer.[/quote]

I heard answering an insulting question with a vague answer that seems to make you think you’re less of a fucknut is completely acceptable.

moparisthebest.com - go there, roam free with your people.

Read full topic
